data.text: Contents
Site team responsibility for initiation and completion .................................................... 9
Presentation and dissemination of harm review findings ............................................ 10
Introduction

In 2016/17 NHS England agreed that local commissioners would monitor individual Trusts against a CQUIN (Commissioning for Quality and Innovation Goal) that focused on ensuring that 100% of patients waiting longer than 104 days from urgent referral for suspected cancer to their first definitive treatment had received a root cause analysis (RCA) of the delay and a clinical harm review.
Clinical harm can be defined as unintended injury resulting from or contributed to by medical care that requires additional monitoring, treatment or hospitalisation or that results in death
In 2018/19 the CQUIN was extended to include all patients who had breached the 62 day target for referral to first treatment.

The rationale for this goal was to ensure that efficient investigation, diagnosis and treatment of cancer occurred as it was essential to ensuring a positive patient experience and improving cancer outcomes.

Whilst there is an acknowledgement that there may be legitimate reasons for some waits, NHS England have set expectations that such long delays should be expected to trigger a review process, so that providers can understand the causes of these long waits and put in place processes to avoid them in future.
Scope

This SOP (standard operating procedure) covers the oversight and management of the process for undertaking a root cause analysis (RCA) and clinical harm review for any patients diagnosed with cancer and who have waited for more than 62 days from urgent GP, Consultant upgrade of screening referral for suspected cancer to first definitive treatment.
The SOP provides guidance on the process for the reporting and investigating of potential harm caused by Cancer Breaches.

The SOP will ensure that patients with a confirmed cancer diagnosis who receive their first definitive treatment after 62 days from urgent referral / consultant upgrade will have their pathway reviewed in accordance with the cancer standards relevant to their cancer pathway.
The SOP incorporates 31 day breaches where the patient is on a 62 day pathway. Where there is a breach of the 31 day target outside of a 62 day pathway, the case will be harm reviewed using this SOP.
The SOP can also be applied to undertake a Harm Review on patients whose care has not met clinically acceptable waiting times despite not breaching 62 or 31 day targets.
The RCA will take into account all contributory factors, including that a patient may choose to wait longer or clinically be unable to be seen or treated within these time frames.
The  SOP  aims  to  provide  assurance  that  all  avoidable  pathway  delays  are monitored and actions implemented to reduce the risk of any future delays and patient harm.
Definitions

table_items.text: GP/GDP/Optometrist referral for suspected cancer requiring appointment within 14 days.

Allocation of breach between Trusts for shared care spells. A tertiary referral should be received at the treatment trust by day 38 of the pathway. The treating trust then has 24 days to treat. For a breached pathway the breach is allocated based on these rules.
Cancer Waiting Times measure the NHS' performance against the national NHS Constitution Standards to monitor the timely delivery of services to patients.

Hospital specialists have the right to ensure that patients who are not referred urgently as suspected cancer referrals or through the screening programmes, but who have symptoms or signs indicating a high suspicion of cancer, are managed on the 62 day pathway. This can be achieved by upgrading the patients onto a 62 day upgrade pathway.
A clinical decision is taken to treat the patient.

Clinically led group that determines the level of investigation required for incidents that have occurred. This group also signs off root cause analysis investigations and action plans as a result of serious incidents, never events and internal investigations.

An intervention intended to manage a patient's condition, disease or injury and avoid further intervention. What constitutes First Definitive Treatment is a matter for clinical judgment, in consultation with others as appropriate, including the patient.
Clinically led panel to review/validate/action completed harm reviews and develop lessons learnt or actions for system where applicable

A MDS form is agreed by the cancer Network to be completed when a patient's care is transferred between NHS trusts. A form provides information to the on the current pathway status of a patient, including the referral and breach dates.
An MDT comprises of medical and non-medical professionals who are responsible for the cancer patient's care. It includes
clinicians from a variety of disciplines, the exact constituent are described for each tumour site as part of Peer Review requirements.

A report used to ensure the maximum waiting time targets are achieved by identifying the patient wait time along that pathways and patients who are at risk of being treated outside the pathway requirements

Root cause analysis (RCA) was developed for the health services to promote a systematic approach to the investigation of serious incidents. A good RCA investigation will identify any underlying system and process issues that may have caused or contributed to the incident.
An incident that occurred in relation to NHS-funded services and care resulting in unexpected or avoidable death, harm or injury to patient, carer, staff or visitor.
A referral received following an investigation as part of a screening programme (Breast, Bowel or Cervical).

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the trust
MSE Cancer Committee:
Ensure that the number of 62+ day breaches by tumour site is a standing agenda item. The data will include completion performance for hospital and breakdown by tumour site;
Receive and monitor the tumour site exception reports as a standing agenda item, ensuring action is taken to mitigate avoidable delays;
Receive a paper incorporating the outcome and themes from HRPs which will be presented to the Quality Committees in Common;
Escalate  and  share  when  appropriate  any  themes/  learning  with  the  STP Cancer Board;
Review all cases where an SI (harm) is identified.
4.1.1 Directorate / Divisional Governance Groups:
Maintain oversight of all Harm Reviews relevant to their directorate, oversee and report all Serious Incidents;
Ensure that the reviews are completed and any actions/learning are shared;
Ensure themes and trends are incorporated into the individual action plans.

Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has robust process in place for harm reviews, oversight of completion, ensuring lessons learnt and actions identified are taken within the organisation.

4.2.1 Managing Director as the site's Accountable Officer is responsible for ensuring the hospital has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.

4.2.2 Director of Operations is accountable for planned care performance, actions taken to mitigate non-performance and ensuring that each responsible service is compliant with governance arrangements in place for their area of responsibility
4.2.3 Associate Director of Nursing for Cancer:
Accountable for maintaining quality of care in cancer. Oversight of serious incidents and resulting root cause analysis;
Ensuring Harm Reviews happen in line with SOP;
Ensure any lessons learnt/actions are followed up and completed.
4.2.4 Associate Directors of Operations, Service Managers & Divisional Clinical Directors:

Accountable for overseeing compliance with this SOP. Ensuring that effective processes are in place to manage patient care and treatment that meet national, local and NHS Constitution targets and standards for each specialty within the relevant division.
4.2.5 Group Clinical Director for Cancer / Site Medical Director:
Expected to chair the panel meetings;
Expected to sign off and confirm the following on the breach report:
4.2.6 Consultants:

Responsible for managing patient care and treatment, working with their Directors/Associate Directors, Service Managers and clinical colleagues to ensure that this is provided within timescales laid down in national, local and NHS constitution targets and standards;
Responsible for completion of clinical harm review for patients breaching cancer standards;
They should attend LHRP or arrange for clinical deputy to attend on their behalf;
They should decide whether the breach was avoidable or unavoidable;
They should decide what level of harm is associated with the breach.
4.2.7 Cancer Services:
Coordinate the harm review process.
Complete Cancer RCA timeline once first treatment is complete.
Report breach onto incident reporting system.
Email out timelines and review document to relevant Governance leads.
Produce ad-hoc reports as required.
4.2.8 Divisional Governance Leads:
Co-ordinate the reviews, ensuring the relevant Clinician receives the paper work in a timely manner;
Ensure that clinical review is undertaken and clinical sign off takes place for each breach;
Quality check completed reviews before forwarding onto the harm panel for sign off;
Return the completed RCA back to the Harm Review Co-ordinator;
Escalate the incident if harm is found, following trust SI process;
Close incidents following confirmation of ‘no harm' following that harm panel.
4.2.9 Clinical Divisional Service Managers:
Review the RCA for each patient within their specialty, ensuring it is a true and accurate representation of the patient journey;
Share breach reports and learning outcomes with their specialty teams;
Ensure trends, themes and actions are captured and presented at the clinical governance boards;
Attend the Harm Review Panel as required and take any remedial actions or
pathway changes for implementation.
4.2.10 Cancer Informatics / Data Lead:
Produce monthly data on submitted breaches;
Enter MDS onto central harm review spreadsheet.
4.2.11 Harm Review Co-ordinator:
To receive completed harm reviews from relevant divisions;
Co-ordinate the LHRP, including room booking and diary requests;
Document outcomes/actions from LHRP;
Feedback outcomes to the relevant division for action;
Update divisions on outcomes, prompting them to close relevant incidents;
Update spreadsheet with incident numbers/dates and outcomes.
Initiation of harm review process
The Cancer Services management team will highlight any patients who have completed first cancer treatment over the  day target and patients who have breached the 31 day standard.
The cancer team will complete a timeline from receipt of referral to first treatment using Somerset.
The cancer team will raise a new incident on the Trust/ site reporting system for each patient who has breached the  day target, entering the patient details and attaching the completed timeline.
The cancer team will review the  day breaches; an incident will only be completed if not already on a 62 day pathway breach (to reduce duplication).
All timelines and incidents will be completed before the close for the treating month's performance.
Site team responsibility for initiation and completion

The clinical/site team responsible for completion of the Harm Review will be decided, in most circumstances, in accordance with Breach Reallocation rules (see appendix 5) but applied across MSE sites/ teams.
Timelines and incident reporting will be initiated and completed by the diagnostic/ referring site team for all patients referred to the treating team after day 38.
Timelines and incident reporting will be initiated and completed by the treating site/ clinical team if referral received prior to day

For patients referred after day  but treated later than  days after referral e.g. the incident will be reported and timeline completed by either the investigating site or the treating site depending on where the greatest length of pathway lay (Appendix 1).
Completion of clinical harm review
6.5.1 The division (operational and governance team) along with the relevant clinical team will complete the harm review within 28 working days using the template provided. (Refer to Appendix 1)

6.5.2 Harm will be assessed using a nationally accepted method to assess the possibility of both physical and psychological harm; requiring answers to 6 questions. (Refer to Appendix 1 and Cancer harm review flow chart)
6.5.3 For shared breaches the outcome/action will be shared across sites. ‘Signed off' reviews should be attached to the incident management system.
Presentation and dissemination of harm review findings

The completing clinician (or an agreed representative) will attend the fortnightly harm review panel to present a summary of the case, including conclusions around any harm and learning from the clinical pathway.
Learning from cases and resulting improvement plans will be reviewed, discussed and collated at Divisional Governance meetings.
Tumour site leads will incorporate outcomes, themes and actions as part of their bi-monthly report to the MSE Cancer Committee.
Local Harm Review Panel (LHRP)
The LHRP will meet fortnightly on each hospital site to review, agree and record the outcome of the Harm Review undertaken by the clinician, including any lessons learnt.
Where no harm has been confirmed, the incident will be closed but any pathway learning incorporated into action plans.
Where possible harm has been identified, the panel will ensure the case has been escalated for immediate review via the Patient Safety team.
The LHRP may suggest a level of harm but this is ultimately to be decided at DRG.
The panel will ensure that any themes for learning are escalated and shared with the MSE Cancer Committee.
The LHRP has defined terms of reference.
(Refer to Appendix 6)
Cancer harm review process
Referral received by the Trust
Patient treated after day 31or 62 – Somerset updated – pathway closed. Breach report completed with timeline and incident reported on Trust system
Completed timeline and request for completion of clinical harm review assigned to the Directorate Governance Manager where breach occurred on Incident Management System. Harm review to determine;
Has the patient undergone any investigations in the last 12 months for the same symptoms, prior to this current referral?
Was a tumour thought to be operable now inoperable as a result of the delay?
Has a delay meant that patient has had to have more radical surgery than first anticipated?
Has a delay meant that disease progression has precluded some treatment options that would have been applicable?
Has a delay in treatment meant that a patient has loss of functionality that is greater than anticipated, commensurate with their disease?
Are you aware of/has there been any prolonged Psychological harm (28 days or more)
Notification of pending harm review sent to Harm Review co-ordinator email.
Directorate presents at harm review panel for agreement of whether the patient has experienced harm due to the delay in treatment during the pathway
If harm to the patient has been identified escalated to Director Review Group for decision to declare as a Serious Incident
RCA to be updated with any agreed corrections post panel review, and Incident Management System to be amended as appropriate
Minutes and action log to be circulated to panel members and clinicians in attendance.
All learning and themes identified through the harm review process shared with Tumour Leads and Cancer Board
Analysis of Harm
RAG / incident reporting ratings
Low:
No apparent injury/adverse outcome,
Minor injury not requiring first aid
Temporary Minor Injury / Illness where First Aid treatment needed, or referral to A&E/OH/GP
days extended stay / <3 days staff absence
Moderate:
Semi-permanent injury,
Moderate Injury from which someone will recover within a relatively short timeframe.
>3 day absence reportable injury to RIDDOR
>3 day extended patient stay
High:
Major injuries, or long term incapacity / disability,
Major Specified Injury (RIDDOR)
Extreme:
Death or major permanent incapacity
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined  below  is  the  Trust's  process  of  monitoring  compliance  with,  and  the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Cancer Harm Reviews Themes and Learning from Cancer Harm
Review of all breached 31/62 day cancer pathways Trust report and key learning

Cancer Harm Review Panel MSE Cancer Committee Cancer Quality Team

data.text: Approval and implementation

All  policies,  procedures  and  guidelines  will  be  approved  by  the  MSE  Cancer Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve procedures for  local  Cancer  Harm  Review  Panels.  These  will  then  be  forwarded  to  the Document  control  team  for  submission  and  ratification  by  the  Joint  Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Site Medical Directors and Harm Review Co-ordinators of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 7)

the delay in diagnostics or treatment impacted adversely on the outcome for the patient.

Appendix 5: Breach Reallocation Framework
Appendix  6: MSE Local Harm Review Panels for Cancer Breaches -
Terms of Reference, July

The Local Harm Review Panels (LHRP) will oversee the cancer clinical harm review process for Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust and will be based on each hospital site. The Harm Review Process will be undertaken by clinicians for all patients referred on an urgent suspected cancer pathway, or consultant upgrade, and with a confirmed cancer diagnosis waiting longer than 62 days for diagnosis or treatment, or  day breaches not on a  day pathway.
The panel will facilitate divisional/ directorate ownership of the clinical harm review process.
Membership of the panel comprises:
Site Medical Director - Chair
Group Clinical Director for Cancer - Deputy Chair
Associate Director of Nursing for Cancer
Cancer Service Manager
Consultant undertaking clinical harm review
Operational Service Manager for the relevant tumour site service
Patient Safety Manager
CCG representative
NHS Specialised Commissioning representative
Primary Care representative
Harm Review Co-ordinator
The Chair or Deputy Chair must be present, as well as the Harm Review Co- Ordinator (or deputy) plus one other member from the group members, in order for the meeting to be quorate
Panel meetings will be held weekly.
The Harm Review co-ordinator will act as the secretary to the panel.
The support provided by the secretariat to the panel will include;
Release of notice of panel dates.
Forwarding  of  documents  received from  Divisions  to  Panel  members  no  later  than  1 working day before the Panel convenes.
Recording the Panel agreed outcome of the harm review undertaken and any comments.
To review all clinical harm reviews undertaken for all patients who have breached cancer standards.
To formally approve the agreed outcome of harm or no harm.
To consider any emerging themes/concerns
Where harm has been identified, to escalate the case to the next Director Review Group (DRG).
To provide assurance to the MSE Cancer Committee, Trust Board, Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Improvement and NHS England of a robust harm review process for patients breaching cancer standards
These terms of reference will be reviewed in line with changes to the Standard Operating Procedure for the MSE Cancer Harm Review Process.
Date of Approval: August 2020 Date of Review: August 2021

☒ A change to an existing document
☒ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
The process has changed significantly since the previous SOP for Cancer RCA's was developed.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
We now have a more robust process which provides monitoring and assurance. The policy now defines the whole process and responsibilities across the Trust.
Who benefits from this change and how?

It will give all cancer MDT's to review the cancer pathway and develop action plans based on learning from Harm Reviews, thus improving patient care and experience, reducing potential of patient harm.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
